trial_identification.studytitle: Reduced Intensity Conditioning Transplantation Versus Standard of Care in Acute Myeloid Leukemia
trial_identification.scientifictitle: Prospective Controlled Clinical Study of Allogeneic Stem Cell Transplantation With Reduced Conditioning (RICT) Versus Best Standard of Care in Acute Myeloid Leukemia (AML)in First Complete Remission (CR)

interventions.interventions:
Treatment: surgery - Reduced Intensity Conditioning Stem Cell Transplantation
Experimental: Stem cell transplant (RICT) - Receiving intervention consisting of Reduced Intensity Conditioning Stem Cell Transplantation
No Intervention: Control arm - Treatment according to standard of care, i.e. not undergoing RICT
Treatment: surgery: Reduced Intensity Conditioning Stem Cell Transplantation One of the following conditioning regimens: Busulphan (orally or IV), fludarabine Fludarabine, carmustine, melfalan Cyclophosphamide, fludarabine

primaryOutcome.outcome: Overall survival at 3 years after inclusion
primaryOutcome.timepoint: From inclusion until death from any cause or after 36 months, whichever comes first

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Time to relapse from inclusion up to 3 years
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Time between inclusion and date of relapse or after 36 months, whichever comes first.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: Quality of life at baseline, 12 and 24 months post inclusion
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: From inclusion (baseline) until relapse or death from any cause or at 12 and 24 months, whichever comes first.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: In RICT patients only: Safety and feasibility of the procedure from inclusion to 3 years
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: Non-relapse mortality (NRM) and overall survival at two occasions up to 36 months after inclusion.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: In RICT patients: Incidence & severity of acute and chronic GvHD from transplantation to three years after inclusion
secondaryOutcome.timepoint: From transplantation until end of study, up to 36 months after inclusion.

secondaryOutcome.outcome: In RICT patients: Rate of complete or partial chimerism from transplant to 3 months

eligibility.inclusivecriteria:
- Newly diagnosed patients with de novo or secondary AML
- Intermediate or poor risk
- In first complete remission
- Age 51-70 years
- Fit for the procedure
- Fit for further consolidation chemotherapy
eligibility.exclusivecriteria: - Planned for a full-dose allogeneic transplant

recruitment.hospital: Austalasian Leukaemia &Lymphoma Group Limited - East Melbourne

othercollaborator.othercollaboratorname: The Canadian Blood and Marrow Transplant Group

ethicsAndSummary.summary:
This study compares overall survival between patients with acute myeloid leukemia, who are in complete remission following initial treatment with chemotherapy and whose remission is maintained either with a transplantation of stem cells obtained from a sibling or unrelated donor or with standard treatment, which is additional chemotherapy.
The study hypothesis is that the group transplanted with stem cells from a donor will have a superior survival compared with patients treated with standard of care.
